results.title: Heads
results.creator_credit: George Dixon, David Corke and Melbourne Repertory Film Unit
results.brief_description: An experimental film by a group of young Victorian filmmakers. Nonchalantly, the cleaner dusts the works of art created by ancient Greek potters, Renaissance painters and modern sculptors. Each piece marks the stage in our progress as percipient thinking beings: civilisations mature and die - but we survive, at least until today. As the cleaner blows dust from the ear of Epstein’s Einstein, he is ignorant of the terrible forces such a mind has unleashed; for good or ill these forces can, almost, be directed by a toss of a coin.

results.title: Flying menace
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes the life cycle of the fruit fly, and the destruction it causes among Australian fruit. Illustrates the precautions being taken by the Department of Agriculture in checking the spread of the menace and shows how farmers should destroy contaminated fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Farewell to childhood
results.creator_credit: Julian Roffman, Herbert Kerkow and Mental Health Film Board
results.brief_description: Shows common problems of adolescents and their parents. A moody 15 year-old girl clashes with her parents when they frustrate her efforts to “run her own life”. Mistakes by the parents, such as scolding her in front of her young escort, widen the rift between parents and daughter. Conditions improve when the girl’s teacher arranges a thorough discussion of adolescent problems, bringing more tolerance to both sides.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julian Roffman, Herbert Kerkow and Mental Health Film Board

results.title: On time
results.creator_credit: Department of the Interior, Eric Thompson and Victorian Railways
results.brief_description: More than 100,000 train passengers pass through the gates at Flinders Street Station, Melbourne each day. Control of passenger and freight trains in and out of the station on time is a masterpiece of precision planning.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Department of the Interior, Eric Thompson and Victorian Railways

results.title: The Queen Returns
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Stanley Hawes and Frank Bagnall
results.brief_description: The visit of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth and His Royal Highness Prince Phillip to Australia. Much of the film is devoted to Canberra and its history as the Queen’s visit coincided with Canberra’s Jubilee Celebrations.

results.title: Game Masters: Blizzard Entertainment interview
results.brief_description:
Blizzard Entertainment is a world leading developer and publisher renowned for creating some of the industry’s most critically acclaimed games. Blizzard’s first success was in 1994 with ‘Warcraft: Orcs and Humans’, a game that laid the foundations for the burgeoning real-time strategy genre, introducing gameplay features that would become standards. In 1996 the company released the action-role-playing-game ‘Diablo’. With a track record that includes thirteen number one games and multiple Game of the Year awards, Blizzard Entertainment has gone on to establish one of the largest online followings of any game company worldwide.

The company is best known for the subscription-based massively multiplayer online role-playing games ‘World of Warcraft’ (2004), and ‘StarCraft’ (1998) series. NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: South Dakota "Dash for Cash"
results.brief_description: You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a hit dystopian TV show – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”, which saw local teachers compete for money to buy school supplies.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a dystopian TV show where contestants risk their lives in murderous games for cash prizes – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”. The people scrambling for $5000 worth of one-dollar bills, while the stadium cheers, are local teachers, who intend to use the money for school supplies. After the footage went viral on social media, it started a seemingly much-needed debate about school funding in America, which saw many teachers reveal that they routinely used their own money to buy classroom necessities, as well as raised questions of how we ended up in a society where desperation is turned into spectacle.

The footage was seen as particularly callous towards South Dakota teachers, who according to CBS News, earn the lowest salary in their profession in America.

“While the Dash for the Cash may have been well-intentioned, it only underscores the fact that educators don’t have the resources necessary to meet the needs of their students,” Loren Paul, president of South Dakota’s teacher union, said in a statement to CBS MoneyWatch. “As a state, we shouldn’t be forcing teachers to wrestle with one another to get the money they need to fund their classrooms.”

At a time when inequality is growing globally and teachers have born the brunt of teaching remotely during the Covid-19 pandemic, more than a few users found the event tasteless at best and at worst, just another sign we’re living in the worst timeline. In response to the backlash, the Sioux Falls Stampede, and CU Mortgage Direct, who fronted the cash, released a statement apologising, saying: “we can see how it appears to be degrading and insulting towards the participating teachers and the teaching profession as a whole.”

The two organisations have since donated a further $15,000 USD to the participants.
description_for_label: You’d be forgiven for mistaking this for a scene out of Squid Game, but unfortunately it’s not a hit dystopian TV show – it’s the Sioux Falls Stampede ice hockey team’s inaugural “Dash for Cash”. The people scrambling for the one-dollar bills (there’s $5000 worth on the ice) while the stadium cheers them on are local teachers, who are going to use the money for school supplies. After the event went viral on social media, it started a debate about funding for schools in America, leading to an additional $500 USD being donated to participants by the event organisers.
